recentPerformance.hitRate: Heat 6-7 but healthy roster with balanced scoring attack
recentPerformance.seasonAverage: Miami averaging 108.2 PPG with defensive identity intact
recentPerformance.recentForm: Won 4 of last 6 games at Kaseya Center, home court providing lift
recentPerformance.cushion: Warriors decimated by injuries - only 8 healthy players available

keyFactors.title: Warriors' Catastrophic Injury Crisis
keyFactors.description: Golden State missing Stephen Curry (knee), Jimmy Butler (traded to Warriors, then OUT with ankle), Jonathan Kuminga (bilateral knee), Al Horford (rest), Draymond Green (questionable). Only 8 healthy players available. This is not an NBA-caliber roster. Championship core completely dismantled by injuries.

keyFactors.title: Heat's Healthy Full Roster
keyFactors.description: Miami has Bam Adebayo, Tyler Herro, Terry Rozier, Jaime Jaquez Jr., Duncan Robinson all available. Full 12-man rotation provides depth advantage against Warriors' 8 healthy bodies. Fresh legs will dominate tired, undermanned opponent.

keyFactors.title: Warriors' Worst Road Defense in NBA
keyFactors.description: Golden State allowing 117+ points per game on road this season, worst defensive rating away from Chase Center. Warriors 2-6 on road because defense collapses without home crowd energy. Heat will score at will against porous road defense.

keyFactors.title: Heat's Elite Home Court
keyFactors.description: Miami 4-3 at Kaseya Center with passionate fan base creating hostile environment. Heat culture thrives at home with Spoelstra's system maximizing home advantage. Warriors' depleted roster will wilt under South Beach pressure.

keyFactors.title: No Offensive Creation for Warriors
keyFactors.description: Without Curry, Warriors have no elite shot creator. Andrew Wiggins and Kevon Looney cannot generate offense against Heat's switching defense. Miami can pack paint and force Warriors into contested mid-range shots.

riskFactors: Double-digit spreads always risky - garbage time can allow backdoor covers
Warriors' role players could have career nights with increased opportunities
Heat might relax with big lead and coast in 4th quarter
Early season variance - any team can win on any night

bamAdebayo.note: Dominated Warriors' frontcourt with 24-14 double-double on 62.5% shooting

tylerHerro.note: 22 points with 7 assists running Heat offense efficiently

terryRozier.note: Steady 18 points as third scoring option, hit clutch 3rd quarter shots

andrewWiggins.note: Led Warriors with 21 but couldn't create for others - isolated scoring

jaimeJaquezJr.note: Energy off bench with 14 points, 7 rebounds - Heat depth advantage

quarterBreakdown.description: Heat established interior dominance early with Adebayo scoring 8 first-quarter points. Miami's ball movement created open looks (7 assists on 10 FGs). Warriors hung around with Wiggins scoring 7 points but couldn't stop Heat's paint attack. 4-point Heat lead after one.

Back-and-forth quarter with teams trading baskets. Heat extended lead to 8 points twice but Warriors answered. Halftime: Heat 49, Warriors 45. Adebayo with 14-8 first half, dominating boards and scoring inside. Heat's 6 turnovers kept Warriors close.

Heat blew game open with dominant 34-point quarter. Rozier hit three consecutive baskets to push lead from 4 to 12. Herro added 10 Q3 points running pick-and-roll. Warriors' 8-man rotation showed fatigue - scored only 24 points on tired legs. Heat lead 83-69 entering 4th. Game effectively over.

Heat maintained comfortable lead throughout Q4. Jaquez's bench scoring (8 Q4 points) kept Warriors at distance. Golden State never got closer than 10 points. Final: Heat 110, Warriors 98 - covered -10 by 2 points.

gameResults.whenCleared: Bet secured when Heat led 104-90 with 3:42 remaining after Adebayo's putback dunk. Warriors made late push (Wiggins 3-pointer at 1:18) but Heat answered with free throws. Final margin of 12 covered -10 by 2 points - sweated but cashed.
gameResults.turningPoint: Third quarter explosion (34-24) transformed close game into comfortable win. Rozier's three consecutive baskets at start of Q3 pushed lead from 4 to 12. Warriors' 8-man rotation couldn't match Heat's depth and fresh legs. When Herro hit step-back three (8:22 left in Q3), lead reached 14 and Warriors broke mentally.
gameResults.gamePace: Heat controlled pace with superior ball movement (26 assists vs 20). Miami's 16 fast-break points vs Warriors' 6 showcased transition advantage from turnovers (10 vs 16). Heat dictated tempo, slowing game to exploit interior dominance.
gameResults.teamOffense: Adebayo's 24-14 double-double anchored balanced attack. Six Heat players scored 10+ points showcasing depth. Warriors' depleted frontcourt had no answer for Adebayo inside. Heat's 54-38 paint advantage epitomized interior dominance without Curry to space floor.

whatWentRight.title: Warriors' Depleted Roster Collapsed
whatWentRight.description: Missing Curry, Butler, Kuminga, Horford left Golden State with G-League caliber depth. Only 8 healthy players couldn't compete with Heat's full rotation. Third quarter fatigue (24 points allowed) showed 8-man rotation breaking down.

whatWentRight.title: Adebayo Dominated Interior
whatWentRight.description: Bam's 24 points, 14 rebounds on 62.5% shooting abused Warriors' depleted frontcourt. No rim protection without their bigs meant easy looks at rim. Heat's 54-38 paint advantage reflected complete interior dominance.

whatWentRight.title: Third Quarter Separation
whatWentRight.description: Heat's 34-24 Q3 broke game open. Fresh legs from full rotation outlasted Warriors' 8-man fatigue. Rozier and Herro's combined 18 Q3 points on efficient shooting showcased depth advantage. This quarter secured the cover.

whatWentRight.title: Turnover Battle Won
whatWentRight.description: Heat's 10 turnovers vs Warriors' 16 created 6 extra possessions. Without Curry's ball handling, Warriors were careless with basketball. Heat's 16-6 fast-break advantage from turnovers added easy points.

statisticalContext.vsSeasonAverage: Heat's 110 points exceeded 108.2 PPG average. Adebayo's 24-14 above his 20-10 averages. Team firing on all cylinders at home.
statisticalContext.vsRecentForm: Warriors' road defensive rating of 117+ continued with 110 allowed. Heat's balanced attack (6 players 10+) ranked 90th percentile for scoring distribution.
statisticalContext.vsPropLine: Covered -10 by 2 points. Lead reached 14 in Q3 and 12 at final. Never dropped below 10-point margin in 4th quarter. Sweaty but successful.
statisticalContext.percentileRanking: Adebayo's 24-14 double-double ranked 85th percentile for his season performances. Heat's 54-38 paint advantage ranked 90th percentile for interior dominance.

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: No. This was complete roster disparity creating expected outcome. Warriors' catastrophic injuries (Curry, Butler, Kuminga, Horford) made them non-competitive against healthy opponent. Adebayo's 24-14 on 62.5% shooting validated interior mismatch thesis. Heat's third quarter dominance (34-24) showed depth > limited roster. Process-driven win from identifying clear edge. Covered by only 2 but controlled game throughout.

closingLineValue.verdict: Positive CLV captured. Line moved from -110 to -115 as money came in on home Heat against depleted Warriors. We bet early at -110 before closing at -115. 5 cents juice saved validates early identification. Game played out exactly as modeled - healthy team vs skeleton crew covers.

keyTakeaways: Warriors' 8 healthy players couldn't compete with Heat's full rotation - always bet healthy teams vs depleted opponents
Adebayo's 24-14 double-double (62.5% FG) dominated without opposing rim protection - target interior mismatches
Heat's 54-38 paint advantage reflected complete interior dominance without Curry spacing floor
Third quarter separation (34-24) validates depth vs fatigue thesis - fresh legs prevail late
Warriors' road defensive rating of 117+ continues to be exploitable - worst road defense in NBA
Six Heat players scored 10+ points showcasing balanced attack that depleted teams cannot defend
Turnover battle (+6) created fast-break advantage (16-6) - ball security matters against pressure
Covered -10 by 2 points - sweaty finish but process was correct, outcome followed
1.5u stake appropriate for clear edge - double-digit spreads risky but injuries justified confidence
For quantitative operations: home teams vs injury-decimated opponents cover spreads at 68%+ rate
verdict: Successful exploitation of injury mismatch despite sweaty finish. Every pre-game thesis materialized: Warriors' catastrophic injuries (Curry, Butler, Kuminga, Horford) created non-competitive roster, Adebayo's 24-14 on 62.5% dominated depleted frontcourt, Heat's third quarter separation (34-24) validated depth vs fatigue, Warriors' worst-in-NBA road defense (117+ DRTG) allowed 110 points. Covered -10 by only 2 points - tighter than expected but controlled game throughout (never trailed in Q4 by fewer than 10). This represents textbook fade of injury-ravaged team. Would make this bet repeatedly - healthy home teams dominate skeleton crews. Captured positive CLV (-110 vs -115). Process-driven win.
